key_points: Winter Storm Lana caused extensive snowfall across parts of Texas, with some areas receiving more than a half foot of snow.
More than 150,000 homes and businesses were left without electricity, with over 100,000 of these outages in Texas alone.
In Tyler, Texas, heavy snowfall caused a tree to fall, damaging a home and two cars, though no injuries were reported.
Schools in Texas, Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama either canceled classes or delayed openings due to the storm.
Louisiana State Police reported numerous crashes and assisted with disabled vehicles due to slick road conditions.
Interstates 49 and 220 near Shreveport, Louisiana, were closed due to the weather, along with several state highways.
Louisiana closed state government offices in 29 parishes in response to the storm, while Hinds County, Mississippi, delayed opening government offices.
Road crews in Jackson, Mississippi, treated icy bridges and warnings of icy conditions extended to the Tennessee and Alabama state lines.
The storm impacted roads in north and north-central Alabama, with continued snowfall reported in several counties.
This report serves as part of The Weather Company's mission to report on breaking weather news and the importance of science.
